titleStmt.title: Here is a lytell shorte cronycle, begynnynge at the. vii. ages of the worlde, w[ith] the comy[n]ge of Brute: and the reygne of all the kynges with the sayntes and martyrs that haue ben in this lande.
Chronicle of all the kings.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Here is a lytell shorte cronycle, begynnynge at the. vii. ages of the worlde, w[ith] the comy[n]ge of Brute: and the reygne of all the kynges with the sayntes and martyrs that haue ben in this lande.
Chronicle of all the kings.
titleStmt.author: Lydgate, John, 1370?-1451?

publicationStmt.publisher: [Imprynted by me Wynkyn de Worde, dwellynge in London in flete strete, at the sygne of the Sonne,
publicationStmt.date: In the yere of our lorde. M. CCCCC. and .xxx. the .xxv. of Iune]] [1530]

notesStmt.note: An edition of the "Chronicle of all the kings".
In two parts. Part 2 title reads:"Here begynneth the cronycle of all ye ky[n]ges names that haue reygned in Englande syth the conquest"; it is a version of John Lydgate's chronicle in verse--STC.
Identified as STC 10012 on UMI microfilm reel 8 and unidentified on UMI microfilm reel 4.
Reproduction of the original in the Cambridge University Library.
Appears at reel 4 (part 2 only) and reel 8 (part 1 only).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- Kings and rulers -- Early works to 1800.

revisionDesc.change: 2006-01 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2006-04 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: ¶Here is a lytell ſhorte Cronycle / begynnynge at the .vij. ages of the worlde / wt the comȳge of Brute: and the reygne of all the kynges / with the ſayntes and martyrs that haue ben in this lande.

div.head: ¶This is the Cronycle of all the kynges names that haue ben in Englande / and how many yeres they reygned / & how many ſeyntes & martyrs haue ben ī this lāde.

list.item: BRute came after ye makȳge of the worlde into this lande / fyrſte called Albyon / in the tyme yt Ely the preeſt of the lawe was in the lande of Iſraell. iiij.M.lxxvii. yere.
¶Newe Troye (that nowe is called London) was founded by the makynge of Brute / after the makynge of the worlde. iiij.M.C.xxiiij. yere.
¶Rome was founded by Remus and Romulus. iiij. • .iiii.C.lxxxxiiii. yere.

¶Ieſu Chryſt was conceyued by the holy ghoſt in ye mayden Marie on a fryday: in the tyme of kȳge Kambalyn / whiche was kynge of Brytayne: the .xv. day of Marche: after the makynge of the worlde. v.M.C.lxxxxix. yere.
¶Ieſu Chriſt was borne / whā his mother was .xiiii yere olde on a ſonday / the .xv. day of December / in the ſame yere: after the makynge of the worlde. v.M.C.lxxxxix. yere.
¶Seynt Iohā the Baptyſt was heded ye .xxv. day of Auguſt after the incarnacyon. xxxii. yere.
¶Ieſu Chriſt ſuffred paſſ • on a fryday / the .xv. day of Marche / after hi • Incarnacyon. xxxiii. yere.
¶Seynt Stephen was martyred the thyrde day of Auguſt / after the incarnacyon xxxiii. yere.
¶Seynt Poule was cōuerted the .xxv. day of Ianuary: after the incarnacyon xxxiiij. yere.
¶Our lady mary was taken into heuen / the .xv. day of Auguſt / in the .lx. yere of her age: after the incarnacyon. xlv. yere.
¶Seynt Longyous was martyred after the Incarnacyon. lvii. yere.
¶Seynt Peter and Paule / were martyred the .xxix. day of Iune / after the incarnacyon lxix. yere.
¶Lucy the kynge of Brytayne became chryſtē / after the incarnacyon C.lxii. yere.
¶Seynt Katheryne was martyred by Maxencius Emperour of Rome / in the tyme that Cōſtātyne ſeynt Elyn ſon was kynge of Brytayne / after the incarnacyon. ii.C.iii. yere.

¶Seynt Vrſula / with the .xi.M. virgyns were martyred at Coleyne: by a Sarazyn yt was called ſwayne / the whiche was kynge of Coleyne in that tyme that Maximian was kynge of Brytayne: after the Incarnacyon ii.C.lxxxxvii. yere.
Seynt Albō was martyred by ye foreſayd Swayne / in the tyme of Maximyan: after the incarnacyon. iii.C.i. yere.
¶Seynt Gregory the pope / ſent into Englande ſeynt Auſtyne / after the incarnacyon. v.C.lxxxxvi. yere.
¶Seynt Edmunde the kynge was martyred by Hū gar and Hubba of Denmarke: in the tyme that fyrſte Alured was kynge of Englande: after the incarnacyon viii.C.lxx. yere.

¶Seynt Edwarde the martyr / was martyred by
his ſtepmother after the incarnacion. ix.C.lxxx. yere.
¶Seynt Edwarde the confeſſour was quycke & deed in the yere of grace. M.lxvi. yere.
¶Seynt Edmunde the kyng was trāſlated the tyme that wyllyam Ruphus was kynge of Englande the yere of grace. M.lxxxxvi. yere.
¶Seynt Edwarde the confeſſour was tranſlated by ſeynt Thomas of Canterbury in the tyme of kynge Henry. ii. yere of grace.
¶Seynt Thomas of Caūterbury was martyred in the ſame kynge Henryes tyme / in the yere of grace. M.C.lxx. yere.
¶The ſame ſeynt thomas was tranſlated in ye tyme of kynge Henry / in the yere of grace. M.CC.xx. yere.

div.head: ¶Theſe ben the Cronycles of the kynges that haue ben ſyth Brute came in to this lande fyrſte.

list.item: ¶Brute came into this lande after the makyng of the Worlde .iiij.M.lxxvij. yere. And he lyued in the lande or he were crowned .xl. yere. And after he was crowned. xx. yere.
Denobaude wan the realme by conqueſte / and reygned. xl. yere.
¶And after this Eſydur / reyned .xxxiii. kynges eche after other in peas / the fyrſt kynge of tho .xxxiii. was Gorbodian / and he reygned. xii. yere.
¶Lud the laſt kynges ſon of .xxxiii. reygned. xi. yere.

div.head: The hole ſūme / from the comȳge of Brute / tyll the Incarnacyon is .M.C.xxii. yere.

list.item: ¶Lucy his ſon reygned an Hethen man. xi. yere.
and a Chriſten man. ii. yere.
¶And afterwarde was ſo great debate in the lāde / yt the realme was without a kynge. l. yere.
¶Coyle that made Colcheſter / was kynge thanne. xiii. yere.
¶Cōſtātyne the Romayne / that wedded ſeynt Elyn / Coyles doughter. xv. yere.
¶Conſtantyne that was emperoure his ſon. xx yere.
¶Octauyan reygned after yt Conſtantyne was gone to Rome to be crowned Emperour xv. yere.
¶Maximian wedded Octautans doughter and reygned .xxviii. yere. in his tyme ſaynt Albon was ſlayne
¶Conſtantyne / coſyn to the kynge of lytell Brytayne reygned. xii. yere.
¶Conſtantyne his ſon that was a mōke at Wyncheſter reygned. v. yere.
¶Forteger that was Erle of Eſſer reygned xi. yere.
¶Engyſt of Saxony in the lande of Germany / that was a Sarazyn / wan the lande & reygned v. yere.
¶Aurylambros Conſtāſtynes ſon ſlewe Engyſt and droue the Sarazyns a way / & reygned viii. yere.
¶Vter pendragon his brother reygned xvii. yere.
¶Garan for Conſtantyne had none heyre xxx. yere.
¶Seynt Ethelbert & Sebert / that were c •• uerted by ſeynt Iuſtyne & his felowſhyp reygned l. yere

¶Elfrede and Cadwaller / ſeynt Oſwalde and ••••
walyn reygned in the realme of Englande one after another. lxxx. yere.
¶Alured the fyrſt / in his tyme ſeynt Edmunde of Bury was ſlayne of Hunger and Hubba / the kynges bretherne of Denmarke xxx. yere.
¶Edwarde the fyrſt his ſon xxv. yere.
¶Seynt Edwarde the martyr his ſon xii. yere.
¶Swayne that was kynge of Denmarke. xv. yere.
¶Edmūde Irenſyde & knowt Swayne ſone. xx. yere
¶Seynt Edwarde the confeſſour Eldredes ſone reygned. xxiii. yere.
¶Harolde / that was godwyns ſone / Erle of weſtſex reygned. i. yere.

div.trailer: Here endeth the Cronycle of all the kynges / that reyned before the conqueſt.
